instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL: What is PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL? This is the voltage coming directly from the charger after going through a transistor. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello all,

I have this 810-00165-A board with no power or green light. I have verified the G3H voltage rails and have found <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> rail to be missing. I traced it back to <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and found that itself is not getting any voltages except <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> on pin 13. The rest of the missing voltages are S5 voltages. Is S5 supposed to come on even when a light has not been produced at the charger tip? <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> are both missing atm. Furthemore the one wire circuit is receiving <SIGNAL>SM_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and it is outputting voltage.

Here are my voltage measurements of the G3Hot lines.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.1V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.1V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> 8.1V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL</SIGNAL> 16.5V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.40V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.33

I found that <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> is outputting on pin 1 a 32khz clock signal. Other than that it seems dormant.

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high and so is <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

Could use a good nudge in the right direction!  Mostly I am not sure if I should see S5 rails even when I have green light missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.1V"
Means communication problem between SMC and <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>; check SCL/SDA lines on diode mode and voltage too.

"<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.33"
Post resistance to ground (diode mode).
Check <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> and any other cap on that line.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: PPBUS has to be 8.6 not 8.1. Post voltage for <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>. Also check resistance to ground on PPVRTC as 2informaticos said. Hopefully the board did not get everything killed on it as sometimes happens if RTC shorts to ground and PPBUS goes to 8.1

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
0.4290 on <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> in diode mode with red lead on ground.  Should this be present as long as there is <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> present on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>?  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5RS3RS0_SYSCLKGEN</SIGNAL> are missing.  I'm guessing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is what feeds what later creates the S5 lines? What voltage is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> once this is properly active?

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> Measures 3.35V
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> SDA measures .4830 on diode mode
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> SCL measures .4906 on diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Either bad ISL or bad SMC causing low PPBUS. Restore PPBUS to 8.6 before we go on to clock voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Tried changing out the ISL but still a 8.1V with PPBUS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Replace SMC time. Has to come from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Oh boy, unfortunately I do not have any donor boards for this. I wonder how worth the risk it is to go and buy one that may also have the same issue.  Anyone on here have one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> and post some voltages for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; pins 10, 11, 12, 13.
Also disconnect LIO flex and see if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> changes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 0V. 
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
Pin 10 3.39V
Pin 11 3.39V
Pin 12 3.39V
Pin 13 3.29V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Looks like SMC issue.
Try reballing it first...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light nor power dead <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks.  I tried reflowing, not reballing.  Don't have a the equipment to reball just yet.  i think im gonna have to call it quits on this one unless the personc an wait until i get parts boards which will take some weeks.

As always I really appreciate all the help! Learning tons here.
